[QUESTION]
Is there a genetic component for happiness?
[ANSWER]
 Studies of twins have shown that about 50% of the variance in happiness can be attributed to genetic factors (Lykken, 1990). The same study also reported that happiness is not related to intelligence, socioeconomic status, or education level.

Do archaeal genomes contain one or multiple origins of replication?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
List symptoms of 4H leukodystrophy.
[ANSWER]
 The most common symptoms are developmental delay, seizures, muscle weakness, and vision loss. Other symptoms may include behavioral changes, such as hyperactivity or aggression, speech difficulties, ataxia, hypotonia, or stiffness.

[QUESTION]
Which genome browser database for DNA shape annotations is available?
[ANSWER]
DNA shape predictions in the UCSC Genome Browser database  were generated by a sliding window approach that calculates the average phylogenetic conservation, GC content, and CpG content of the window. The UTRs of protein-coding genes are not considered separately in these predictions.

[QUESTION]
Why are insulators necessary in gene therapy vectors?
[ANSWER]
 Insulaters are used to prevent the activation of a therapeutic gene by neighboring enhancer or promoter elements. In the absence of an insulator, a gene may not be expressed at the expected level, or may be silenced due to the influence of neighbor ing enhancers or silencers.

[QUESTION]
How is the sequence variability defined in antibodies?
[ANSWER]
 In principle, the number of possible sequences can be very large, even if the length of the sequences is short. For example, a 10-mer peptide has 313 possible antibody sequences, although this number is reduced to 212 if only 4 residues are considered.

[ANSWER]

[ANSWER]

[ANSWER]
 To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to utilize proteomic analysis in Pick’s, a disease with a dearth of biomarker literature. Here we show that Pick bodies are unique structures with specific proteome profiles, distinct from intracellular neurofibrillary tangles.

[QUESTION]
Is the Miller-Fisher syndrome considered to be a variant of Guillain-Barré?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is yes. The Miller Fisher syndrome, a rare variant, accounts for only 5% of the cases of GBS. It is characterized by the presence of anti-GQ1b antibodies.

[QUESTION]
Are retroviruses used for gene therapy?
[ANSWER]
 Yes, retroid elements have been used in gene transfer. In one approach, a vector is engineered to contain a replication-defective retrivirus genome with an insert of a therapeutic gene. This vector may be delivered into the target cell in an integrative or nonintegrative manner.

[QUESTION]
Explain the concept proteostasis.
[ANSWER]
 Proteostatic processes are important for maintaining the cellular environment to ensure proper protein production and function. These processes include protein synthesis, folding, trafficking, degradation, and the regulation of these processes.

Are there randomised controlled trials on sevoflurane?
[ANSWER]
 No. Are trials feasible? Yes. Do we know the size of the effect? Only very approximately. Is it ethical to withhold a drug that is safe and effective in most patients? Possibly not. Should we wait for a trial to provide data? Probably not, since the delay would be many years.

[QUESTION]
What causes Katayama Fever?
[ANSWER]
 The disease is thought to be caused by the degranulation of mast cells in the dermis by mites or their secretions. This degradation leads to the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators, causing an acute allergic reaction .

[QUESTION]
Is the Prostate- Specific Antigen (PSA) test relevant only for prostate cancer?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is no. The PSA test is also relevant for monitoring the evolution of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The normal value of PAS is less than 4 ng/mL.

What are the properties of super-enhancers?
[ANSWER]

Super enhancing regulates the expression of key developmental transcription factors and is essential for lineage commitment and cell identity. Genes that are regulated by super enhancesers are often highly expressed

[QUESTION]
Is the length of the poly(A) tail involved in human disease?
[ANSWER]
 The length and the structure of polyadenosine tails are important in the regulation of mRNA stability and translation. The addition of a poly (A)-tail to an RNA transcript is a crucial step in processing eukaryotic pre-mRNAs to mature m-RNPs.

[QUESTION]
What are the Topological Domains (TADs)?
[ANSWER]
 TAD refers to a local region of the genome in which the frequency of physical contact between two loci is more common than would be expected at random. Tads are typically defined by the presence of CTCF binding sites, which form boundaries that restrict the spatial movement of DNA. The CTCT motif of this

[QUESTION]
What is the vibrational theory of olfaction?
[ANSWER]
 The vibrations of the odorant molecules are the stimuli, and the olfactory receptors are specialized sensors that resonate with these vibration frequencies. The olfactometer is a device that exposes the resonating olfactoral receptor cells to the desired odors.

[QUESTION]
Which  is the execution time (complexity) of the Smith-Waterman algorithm for the alignment of two sequences
[ANSWER]
 of length L1 and L2, respectively? The problem is to find the optimal alignment. Let be the matrix of dimension L 1×L 2 of scores of local alignments between the two given sequences. The time needed to fill the dynamic programming matrix is O(L1L2).

What is the treatment of Riedel disease (thyroiditis)?

What is DNAshape?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is the Pfam database?
[ANSWER]
 Pfams (PF) are collections of proteins with similar functions that are grouped together on the basis of their sequence alignments and structural characteristics. The PfAM database is a collection of protein domain families that is searchable via the internet (http://pfam.sanger.ac.uk/).

[ANSWER]

Are there Conserved Noncoding Elements (CNEs) in invertebrate genomes?

[QUESTION]
Describe armoured brain syndrome.
[ANSWER]
 Armoured Brain Syndrome is a condition whereby the brain appears shrunken and hardened, with a thickened leptomeningeal layer and a thin cerebral cortex. This condition is most commonly found in patients with neurocysticercosis.

What is a disordered protein?
[ANSWER]
 A protein is said to be disorganized if it does not have a unique 3D structure, but rather adopts multiple conformations that are in dynamic equilibrium. Conformational flexibility is an important feature of proteins, which allows them to perform their functions and adapt to changes in the cellular environment. Prote

[QUESTION]
What are the main benefits of pharmacophore models?
[ANSWER]
 The main benefit of using a pharmacy model is that the model can be used to screen a large number of compounds that have similar properties. It is difficult to test a lot of drugs. The pharmaceutical model allows only the best candidates to be selected for further testing.

[QUESTION]
What causes Scurvy?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is simple: a lack of vitamin C. The body is unable to synthesize vitamins from sunlight or food alone; the body needs vitamic C to metabolize protein. Without this vitamine, the human body cannot metabolic protein and therefore cannot survive.

[QUESTION]
What are prions?
[ANSWER]
 Prions are a type of protein that form aggregates in cells. These aggregations can spread from cell to cell, and can cause a variety of diseases in humans and animals. Prion diseases are also known as transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) .

What is Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)?
[ANSWER]
 CJ is a rare, progressive neurodegenerative disease. It is fatal and affects the brain and nervous system. Cases of CVD can be sporadic, inherited or acquired. The spongiform form of the disease is the most common.

[QUESTION]
What do statins do?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is the function of Oseltamivir when administered during flu?
[ANSWER]
 A 2008 study found that Osletamvivir was effective at reducing symptoms in the early stages of infection, but that it had no effect on the progression of the disease . This means that the drug is good for reducing the length of symptoms of flu, not the duration of illness.

[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
Is scuba diving safe during pregnancy?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
Which algorithm is used by the UCSC Genome Browser?
[ANSWER]
 In the case of DNA, the genome browser uses a method called N-best banding. It finds all the regions of equal conservation score and picks the highest scoring one. In our case, it is equivalent to the algorithm used in the multiple alignment.

[QUESTION]
What is the purpose of the FRAX scale?
[ANSWER]
 Fracture risk assessment tools provide an estimate of an individual’s risk of fracture over a fixed time period, usually ten years. They are designed to be used in decision-making about prevention strategies to reduce the risk.

[QUESTION]
What are the 4 cardinal signs of inflammation according to Celsus?
[ANSWER]
 According to this theory, there are 5, not 6, cardinals signs: fever, swelling, pain, redness, and loss of function. The fifth sign, loss or change of tissue function, is not always present in inflammatory processes.

[QUESTION]
Do bacteria from the genus Morexella cause respiratory infections?
[ANSWER]
 Yes, bacteria of the M. catarrhalis species cause intra- and extracellular respiration in the human body.

[QUESTION]
What causes "Puffy hand syndrome"?
[ANSWER]
The exact mechanism of puffy hands is unknown. Several theories have been proposed, including venous congestion, arterial concomitants, and lymphatic obstruction, but none of them has been proven.

[QUESTION]
Describe swirl sign in intracerebral hemorrhage.
[ANSWER]
 Swirl signs are defined as a swirling pattern of hypoattenuation that can be seen on CT or hyperintensity on T2-weighted sequences that reflects the mixing of blood products within the hematoma cavity.

[QUESTION]
What is the most common histological diagnosis of "butterfly glioma"?
[ANSWER]
 The term "glioma" is a misnomer for these tumors and the correct term is "hemangiopericytoma". These lesions are closely related to meningiomas and are believed to arise from pericytes that surround capillaries.

[QUESTION]
What is the phenomenon of gene kissing?
[ANSWER]
 The phenomenon is called gene-gene interaction or gene pair interaction . The concept of this phenomenon was first proposed by C. H. Waddington in 1942, who proposed that the gene function is not isolated, but interacts with other genes . This phenomenon has been confirmed by many subsequent studies .

[QUESTION]
What is the mode of action of the drug Prolia?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
Is trastuzumab associated cardiotoxicity reversible?
[ANSWER]
 Yes. Most cases of reversibility have occurred within 2-4 weeks after stopping trasteuzmab. If the ejection fraction is lower than 50% after chemotherapy, the trazustumal administration should be delayed until the cardiac function recovers.

[QUESTION]
Which are the constitutive parts of a Genomic Regulatory Block (GRB)?
[ANSWER]
 A GRB is composed of: (i) a set of genes (typically 10-400) and (ii) the regulatory sequences that control their expression. In our model, the GRBScore is computed by a matrix multiplication between the expression matrix and the weights matrix.

[QUESTION]
Is creatinine assessment included in the MELD score?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is yes; however, it is included as a negative value in case of liver transplantation, which may result in lower MELDS. This can be a significant factor in patients with cirrhosis who need transplants.

[QUESTION]
What cellular process are okazaki fragments associated with?
[ANSWER]
 Okazakis fragments are single stranded DNA fragments produced during DNA replication and are involved in the process of DNA repair. The fact that they are associated to the nucleus and the centromere (DAPI staining) could be a reflection of this process.

[QUESTION]
What is the aim of the 4D nucleome project?
[ANSWER]
 The goal of our project is to map chromatin folding in space and time in living cells. We aim to reconstruct the dynamic 3D chromosome architecture and investigate how it is regulated in response to various stimuli and how this architecture impacts cellular functions.

What is Alzheimers disease resilience?
[ANSWER]
 We have suggested that the brain is well-poised to adapt to damage. We propose that resiliency encompasses both aspects of this equation.

[QUESTION]
What is the BioArchive system?
[ANSWER]
 The Bioarchive is an integrated system of the AMS, the national DNA bank and the NBR of Japan. The AoU-TDC is currently responsible for the management of this system, with the support of NIBR and NFRC.

[QUESTION]
Which gene is responsible for red hair?
[ANSWER]
 The gene responsible is called the melanocortin-1 receptor (MC1R). It is the same gene that determines whether a person will have light or dark eye color. It was discovered in 1998.

What is the Formalin test used for?
[ANSWER]
The formalin-test is used to test the potency of formaldehyde as a germicide, to determine the concentration of available formaline in a solution, and to detect formal-resistant strains of microorganisms.

[QUESTION]
How can PEGylation improve recombinant drugs?
[ANSWER]
PEGyation is a common strategy for improving recombination drugs. The mechanism of action of PEGE is that it can reduce the clearance of drugs in vivo, increase the circulation time of the drug in the body, reduce immunogenicity, and improve the solubility of proteins.

Does simvastatin improve outcomes of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is CIBERSORT used for?
[ANSWER]
 Cibersort is a deconvolution algorithm that can be used to estimate the proportions of immune cell types within a complex gene expression mixture. It is designed to provide an accurate and robust estimation of cell fractions from bulk tissue gene-expression data.

What is the cause if the rare disease cystinosis?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is known about the gut bacteria and depression.
[ANSWER]
 Previous studies have found a link between gut microbiota and the development of depression, indicating that microbial metabolites and inflammatory factors play a role in the pathogenesis of MDD. However, whether gut bacterial transplantation is an effective treatment for depression remains uncertain.

What is the exoproteome?
[ANSWER]
 It is a sub-proteome that is not only important but also essential for many functions of bacteria. The exo-secretome is also important for the bacteria themselves, as it allows the secretion of proteins that are toxic to the bacterial cells, which is important to maintain the integrity of the cell wall

How can super-enhancers be used in disease diagnosis?
[ANSWER]
 Super- enhancers can be identified in the same way as described above. The major difference is that the super enhancer sequences from disease samples are compared to those from the normal samples. Thus, the disease specific superenhancer is identified by comparing the two different samples (see Figure 2).

[QUESTION]
Is the Philadelphia chromosome a fusion between parts of chromosomes 1 and 9?
[ANSWER]
 No, the fusion is between the long arms of both chromsomes, with breakpoints at q22 and q34. In other words, there is a reciprocal translocation between long-arm segments of different chromsome pairs.

[QUESTION]
Describe the Disambiguate algorithm and its application in next generation sequencing data
[ANSWER]
. The DisAmb algorithm is a two-stage process. In the first stage, each variant is assigned an initial probability of being a mutation site. This probability is calculated based on the number of reads that support a variant and the total number that cover the variant.

Which algorithm has been developed for detecting expansions of tandem repeats?
[ANSWER]
 The algorithms can be divided into the following three categories: algorithms based on the analysis of the coverage depth of short reads, algorithms that utilize the length of readings, and algorithms using the information on mismatches in the sequencing reads. The latter two categories include a number of algorithms for the detection of STRs.

Rachmilewitz Index is used for which diseases?
[ANSWER]
Rachmielwicz index is a grading system to assess the severity of liver damage in patients with chronic hepatitis B. It is based on the examination of the liver and blood test results.

[QUESTION]
What does a PET (Positron Excitation Tomography) measure?
[ANSWER]
 A P-ET scan is a medical test that uses a radioactive tracer to measure the metabolic activity of body tissues. PEA (PET Arterial) is the arteriographic technique that measures the blood flow rate of the heart, brain and other organs.

[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is the basis of the methidiumpropyl-EDTA sequencing (MPE-seq) method?
[ANSWER]
 In the MPE protocol, DNA is treated with methylpropanol-bisulfite followed by incubation with a mixture of EDTA and proteinase K (10). The mixture is then heated to 80°C for 30 min to release the DNA from the protein.

[QUESTION]
Describe the mechanism of action of Trilaciclib.
[ANSWER]
 Tricicliclib is a selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) 4 and 6. It blocks the cell cycle in the G1 phase and inhibits the proliferation of tumor cells.

Which gene is mutated in the classic Bartter's syndrome?
[ANSWER]

[QUESTION]
What is the purpose of the Unique Connectivity of Uncharged Compounds (UC2) search tool?
[ANSWER]
The purpose is to allow the exploration of compounds within a user-defined connectivity threshold. The UC2 search is a powerful tool that allows for the identification of potential drug targets and the analysis of compound clusters. It has been used to identify potential targets for several diseases, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases

[QUESTION]
What does the Smith–Waterman algorithm do?
[ANSWER]
 It aligns two sequences (A and B) by extending an anchor in sequence B that has been previously extended. It extends by matching a sequence of nucleotides in A that is as long as possible. The anchor is extended until the sequence in the two genomes does not match. This process is then repeated by

[ANSWER]
Patients with Allgove syndrome have the following symptoms: failure to thrive, hypotonia, developmental delay, mental retardation, seizures, cataracts, liver dysfunction, pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, diabetes mellitus, and short stature.

 In the nucleus, it binds to the DNA and regulates transcription. In other cell compartments, its function is unknown.

[QUESTION]
Which method is behind HipMCL?
[ANSWER]
 HIP-Hop is a clustering method that uses the idea of the k-means algorithm. It works by selecting a set of representative points, called centroids, which represent the different clusters. The centroides are then used to assign each point to the appropriate cluster.

[QUESTION]
What is a decoy exosome?
[ANSWER]
 A decory exsomes is an exomes that contains none or few of the mutant genes. The decry exsome is isolated from a patient who has the same cancer as the patient of interest but does not have the specific mutation of that patient.

[QUESTION]
Can you summarize Myasthenia Gravis?
[ANSWER]
 This is a rare autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction, affecting 1 in 800–120,061 people (1:709 in the UK) . It can be a severe, life-threatening condition that requires early diagnosis and treatment.

Intellectual disability, congenital cataracts, and facial dysmorphism

 as a function of the kappa statistic.CrossICCC=1+(N−1)Kappa, where Kappa=Po(a)Po+a(1−Po)a+1,and Po is the probability of agreement.

[ANSWER]
 MRAs block the aldosterone receptors in the kidneys and the heart, which reduces sodium retention and potassium excretion. By blocking these renal reductors, MRas can treat hypertension and HF.

[QUESTION]
What is hypercapnia?
[ANSWER]
Hypercapnic respiratory failure is characterized by an increase in the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) above 60 mmHg (8 kP) as a result of a respiration defect or an acute increase of CO2 production, or both .

[QUESTION]
Is progeria caused by an autosomal recessive gene?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is yes. There is a mutation in the LMNA gene that causes prog-gera. The Lmna gene codes for a protein called lamin A, which is involved in maintaining the structure of the nucleus. This mutated protein leads to early aging and death.

[QUESTION]
What is a foam cell?
[ANSWER]

Which pharmacogenetic test is recommended prior to administering carbamazepine and why?
[ANSWER]
There is insufficient evidence to recommend a specific pharmaco-genetic assay prior the administration of carbame-pazine. However, testing for the CYP2C9 *2 allele is suggested before the initiation of treatment.

[QUESTION]
Explain the association between Barr bodies (nuclear inclusions) and the X chromosome?
[ANSWER]
 The sex chromatid body is a nuclear body in the nucleus of cells with a XX karyotype. The chromatin of the sex body comes from the inactivated X-chromosomes, which are packed into a large spherical body and usually localize at the periphery of nuclei.

[QUESTION]
Does a comet assay measure radiation induced mutations?
[ANSWER]
 No. A cometary tail provides a measure of the amount of DNA damage in a sample, but does not provide any indication of what type of mutation is induced.

What is the mechanism of action of Vericiguat?
[ANSWER]
 Verisguat is a sGC activator. It binds to sCG to promote the formation of cGMP from GTP. The increase in intracellular c-GMB levels leads to vasodilation.

[QUESTION]
What is the synonym of MK-1602?
[ANSWER]
 It is not a drug, but an “investigational drug” used for research purposes. It means that M-K1 is an experimental drug that is being investigated and has not been approved by the FDA. In other words, it is a research drug with no known side effects.

[QUESTION]
What is a circRNA?
[ANSWER]
 CircRNAs are formed from exons of protein-coding genes via a back-splicing mechanism, where a downstream 5′ splice site is covalently joined to an upstream splash site, forming a closed circular molecule with no 3′ or 4′ ends.

[QUESTION]
What is the mechanism of action of Gemogenovatucel-T?
[ANSWER]
 Gemagenovatelucellysate is taken up by MHC-I and MCH-II expressing cells. The viral genome is then released into the cytosol. Viral DNA is transported to the nucleus where it is integrated into host DNA and viruses are replicated.

[QUESTION]
Is Satb1 a transcription factor?
[ANSWER]
 The answer to this question is still unclear. Although Satbl1 has been shown to bind DNA in vitro and in vivo, it is not clear that it functions as a gene-specific transactivator. The lack of a clear DNA-binding domain makes it difficult to identify Sat1-bound sequences.

[QUESTION]
What is the half-life of epimutations across generations of C. elegans?
[ANSWER]
 Epimutatations show a rapid decay over 50 generations (with some exceptions), which might be due to genetic drift. However, a small fraction of these mutations might persist across many generations, and thus be considered as epialleles.

[QUESTION]
Is there a way to distinguish COVID-19 clinically from other respiratory illnesses, particularly influenza?
[ANSWER]
 The answer is yes. Although symptoms are similar, influenzavirus causes acute respira-tory illness with fever, cough, and nasal congestion, whereas COVID‐10 causes fever with dyspnea, fatigue, dry cough and anosmia.

What is Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS)?
[ANSWER]
GBSGBS is an immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system (PNS). It is the most common cause of acute weakness in adults and can affect any age group. The symptoms vary widely and include progressive weakness and abnormal sensation in the legs, arms, or both

[QUESTION]
Is lumbar puncture the first test that should be performed on a patient with increased intracranial pressure?
[ANSWER]
 In some cases, other tests should precede this procedure. For example, in patients with suspected meningitis or encephalitis, a blood culture should first be drawn, followed by a lumbo-cisternal punctue.

[QUESTION]
How does condensin affect the function of topoisomeraseII?
[ANSWER]
 In top1Δ or top2Δ cells, the DNA is relaxed and does not require the action of condensing enzymes. In these cells the condensed chromosome is still formed. This strongly suggests that condensisn plays a role in the maintenance of DNA topology rather than in chromatin formation.

What are the functions of DNA and RNA G-quadruplexes?
[ANSWER]

In this respect, it is important to note that G4s are usually observed in the promoter regions of genes with a high expression level, suggesting that these non-coding regions can be responsible for the transcription regulation.

 In the following, we will discuss the most important characteristics of this algorithm. The CCR is used for patients with a NEXUS low risk or Canadian triage and acuity scale (CTAS) I or II. These are patients who present to the ED with neck pain and no other neurological symptoms.

[QUESTION]
Is telomestatin, a novel statin drug used to treat high cholesterol?
[ANSWER]
 No, it is not. Telomastatin is an antifungal compound from Streptomyces hygroscopicus. It is also known as beauvericin and is used in agriculture to control fungal infections .

[QUESTION]
What is the use of Brain Metastasis Velocity (BMV) Model?
[ANSWER]
 It is a useful tool for clinicians to determine the most appropriate management strategies for their patients. It can be used to guide treatment decisions, such as whether to perform surgical resection, use radiation therapy, or initiate systemic therapy. [QUESTION]
Is Ameloblastoma (AB) a benign tumor that never metastasizes?
[ANSWER]
 This is a common misconception. Amelo-blastoma is considered ben-ignant because it is slow growing, well-defined, and has a good prognosis. However, AB can recur and metas-tasize, especially the multicystic variant .

[QUESTION]
What are the targets of avapritinib?
[ANSWER]
Avaprinitib is a highly selective tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets KIT, PDGFRA, and PDGRB. It is approved for the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) and mastocytosis.

[QUESTION]
Is PPROM a condition that occurs in males or females?
[ANSWER]
 How does PROM affect the male fetus? We have no evidence to suggest that the fetal sex affects the occurrence of PPRM. In addition, the fact that PRM affects both male and female fetuses suggests that there are no sex-specific effects of the condition.
